title: How to Reduce Water Usage in the Garden

steps.headline: Buy a watering can.
steps.description: This will enable you to carry on watering your garden during times when hose pipe bans are in force and will substantially reduce water consumption in comparison to hose pipes.

steps.headline: Purchase a water butt.
steps.description: Attach the water butt to your roof drainage system so that any rainwater that lands on your roof is stored. Ensure that an overflow pipe is fitted encase your water butt fills up. Where possible make the overflow pipe feed into the soil so that excess water isn't wasted or passed into local sewage/drainage systems.

steps.headline: Use water from a water butt.
steps.description: Using the watering can and the stored water from the water butt, water your plants and your grow your own produce accordingly.

steps.headline: Do not water plants during times of heat.
steps.description: Ensure that you water your garden at the coolest times of the day (i.e. first thing in the morning) as this will reduce the amount of water that is evaporated from your lawn and plants. But don't water at night because that can lead to root rot.

steps.headline: Increase water retaining capability of soil.
steps.description: To increase the water retaining capability of your soil purchase some water retention gel and mix with the soil within your tubs and containers. The water retaining crystals will absorb water ensuring that water is kept within the soil and not simply passed out of the planting area.

steps.headline: Increase stress tolerance of plants.
steps.description: Purchase stress tolerance enhancers and apply them to your plants to further reduce the need for watering.

steps.headline: Have native plants and vegetables.
steps.description: Ensure that your garden includes plants and veg that are native to your region and are therefore more likely to require less water than plants from other countries or continents.

steps.headline: Relocate plants.
steps.description: Try moving plants from normal soil into containers and tubs as they will hold water for much longer than normal garden soil/compost. A substantial amount of water passed into the normal garden soil will be passed further down into the earth.

steps.headline: Consider a drip irrigation system.
steps.description: You can save up to 75% on water usage over conventional watering systems.

steps.headline: You can plant with plasticulture.
steps.description: Polyethylene (PE) is the plastic film used by the majority of growers it comes in a variety of thicknesses. This is beneficial to plant growth such as reduced water loss, UV stabilization to cool soil and prevent insects, elimination of Photosynthetically active radiation to prevent weed growth.
